title: Sneaker Marketplace StockX Seeks New Customers With Bleacher Report Deal
text:
Online sneaker marketplace StockX LLC has struck an advertising deal with WarnerMedia’s Bleacher Report as it seeks to step up its marketing efforts in an increasingly competitive business.

The multiyear deal will include paid ads, links to drive Bleacher Report users to StockX’s marketplace, custom videos and sponsored articles on Bleacher Report, and a physical space at Bleacher Report’s annual sneaker-focused event, The Drop Up, in December.

StockX is paying Bleacher Report an undisclosed fee and will share revenue from any sales to visitors who arrive via a Bleacher Report link, according to executives from Bleacher Report and StockX.

Newsletter Sign-up

Launched in 2016, StockX is an online marketplace that lets users buy and sell sneakers and other fashion items. It emulates a stock exchange by providing market data such as 52-week high and low prices.

Sneaker resale is becoming a fiercely contested market as a raft of sites vie to cater to often-young shoppers who collect rare merchandise and try to sell it at a markup online.

A pair of Nike Dunks that once retailed for $200 sold on StockX in July for $13,500.

The growth has fueled new funding. In February, Foot Locker Inc. said it was investing $100 million in Goat Group, an online sneaker reseller. Last December, Farfetch Ltd. said it was acquiring Stadium Goods in a deal valued at $250 million.

StockX in June closed a $110 million funding round that valued the company at $1 billion.

The Bleacher Report deal is StockX’s first effort to lure users to its online marketplace with content from a media partner, StockX Chief Executive Officer Scott Cutler said. He added that the company could form similar tie-ups with other partners.

“We want to be in the places where our community is convening and gathering information,” Mr. Cutler said. “As we grow into the next phase of our business—we have customers in 170 countries around the world and are rapidly expanding outside of the U.S.—we expect to expand these types of partnerships at a global level.”

Related Video Sneaker Con co-founder Yu-Ming Wu and Hayden Sharitt, a 21-year-old resale business owner, take us inside the industry where some sellers make millions of dollars on pre-owned shoes, as they attend a sneaker trading show in Cleveland. Photo/Illustration: Tyler Clark/Drew Evans

Bleacher Report’s Kicks franchise has 1.3 million followers on Instagram, with celebrity followers including LeBron James, Kevin Durant and Justin Timberlake.

But Bleacher Report can also help StockX expand beyond hard-core sneakerheads, said Howard Mittman, chief executive of Bleacher Report. “They have a big business in selling other products than just sneakers, and we can help them branch out and reach more casual fans,” he said.

Bleacher Report’s parent company, WarnerMedia, is part of AT&T Inc.

Mr. Cutler said StockX’s marketing spending is rising in line with its overall business, but declined to give a number. StockX has previously set up marketing installations at events like South by Southwest in Austin, Texas, and ComplexCon in Long Beach, California.

StockX is on pace to facilitate more than $1 billion in transactions this year, according to the company. The company has previously said its platform could handle more than $6 billion of annual sales by 2025.

StockX makes money by collecting a 3% processing fee, plus transaction fees that range from 9.5% for sneakers and streetwear to 14.5% for handbags. Its revenue has doubled over the past year, the company said.

Corrections & Amplifications

An earlier version of this article misstated the surname of StockX Chief Executive Officer Scott Cutler as Cullen. (9/11/19)
description: StockX LLC has struck an advertising deal with WarnerMedia’s Bleacher Report as it seeks to step up its marketing efforts in the competitive sneaker-resale business.
